name: Deep Sea Fishing
description: Venture into the Gulf of Mexico for an unforgettable offshore fishing adventure targeting trophy fish.
longDescription: Deep sea fishing from Port Aransas takes you miles offshore into the Gulf of Mexico, where blue water holds some of the most exciting game fish in Texas. Charter boats leave at dawn, heading for oil rigs, artificial reefs, and natural structure where red snapper, king mackerel, amberjack, and even billfish prowl. Trips range from half-day excursions to overnight adventures, with party boats and private charters available for all budgets.
tips: Take motion sickness medication the night before, not morning of
Eat a light breakfast, avoid greasy foods
Bring cash for tips (15-20% is customary)
Book well in advance during summer
Party boats are more affordable but less personalized

operators.name: Deep Sea Headquarters
operators.description: Fleet of party boats and private charters, operating since 1967

operators.name: Captain Clark's Flagship
operators.description: Large party boat with covered areas, good for families

faqs.question: Do I need a fishing license?
faqs.answer: Licensed charter boats include licenses for all passengers. You only need your own license if fishing from shore or a private boat.

faqs.question: What happens to the fish I catch?
faqs.answer: Most charters clean and bag your catch at no extra charge. You'll need a cooler with ice to transport it.

faqs.question: Will I get seasick?
faqs.answer: Some people do. Take motion sickness medication the night before and morning of. Stay in fresh air, avoid the engine area, keep your eyes on the horizon.

name: Bay & Inshore Fishing
description: Target redfish, speckled trout, and flounder in the calm waters of Redfish Bay and surrounding flats.
longDescription: Bay fishing in Port Aransas offers a different experience than offshore—calmer waters, lighter tackle, and the thrill of sight-casting to tailing redfish on the flats. The extensive bay systems, grass flats, and marsh edges provide habitat for redfish, speckled trout, flounder, and black drum. Guided trips use shallow-draft boats to access skinny water, where you might pole across knee-deep flats in pursuit of trophy fish.
cost: $350-$600 for half-day charter, $550-$800 for full day
tips: Polarized sunglasses are essential for sight fishing
Listen to your guide—they know where fish are

operators.name: Redfish Bay Charters
operators.description: Specializing in sight-casting and fly fishing

faqs.question: What fish will we catch?
faqs.answer: Primarily redfish, speckled trout, and flounder. Black drum and sheepshead are also common.

faqs.question: Is bay fishing good for beginners?
faqs.answer: Excellent for beginners. Calmer water, lighter tackle, and guides who can teach casting techniques.

name: Jetty Fishing
description: Fish from the massive rock jetties protecting the ship channel for a unique shore-based experience.
longDescription: The Port Aransas jetties are massive rock structures extending into the Gulf, creating excellent fishing habitat. The rocks provide structure for baitfish, which attract redfish, trout, snook, tarpon, and various offshore species. Fishing the jetties requires careful footing on the rocks but rewards anglers with shore access to typically boat-only species. The south jetty is accessible by vehicle; the north jetty requires crossing by ferry.
requirements: Good balance for walking on rocks
whatToBring: First aid kit for cuts from rocks
tips: Watch where you step—rocks can be slippery
Incoming tide best for most species
Bring tough tackle—you'll get hung up
Target species change by location on jetty

faqs.question: Which jetty is better?
faqs.answer: Both produce fish. South jetty is easier to access by car. North jetty requires ferry but can be less crowded.

faqs.question: Is it safe to fish from the jetties?
faqs.answer: Use caution—rocks are uneven and can be slippery. Wear shoes with good grip, never fish alone, and watch for waves.

name: Pier Fishing
description: Fish from Horace Caldwell Pier without needing a boat, with rod rentals and bait available on-site.
longDescription: Horace Caldwell Pier extends into the Gulf, providing easy access to good fishing without a boat. The pier house sells bait, rents rods, and provides tackle, making it perfect for casual anglers or families introducing kids to fishing. Catches include redfish, trout, sheepshead, whiting, and occasional larger species that patrol the structure.
whatToBring: Bucket for catch (or bring for cleaning)
tips: Best fishing at dawn and dusk
Live shrimp is the most versatile bait
Ask the pier staff what's biting

faqs.question: Do I need my own equipment?
faqs.answer: No—the pier house rents rods and sells bait. Just show up and fish.

faqs.question: Good for kids?
faqs.answer: Excellent for kids. Easier than shore fishing, with facilities nearby and rental equipment available.

name: Surfing
description: Catch waves along the Port Aransas beaches where consistent Gulf swells create beginner-friendly conditions.
longDescription: Surfing in Port Aransas won't rival Hawaii, but the Gulf of Mexico delivers consistent small-to-medium waves perfect for learning and longboarding. Winter months and storm fronts generate the best swells, while summer offers gentle waves ideal for beginners. Local surf shops provide lessons, board rentals, and current condition reports. The sandy bottom and warm water make it a forgiving environment for new surfers.
bestTime: Early morning before wind picks up
tips: Morning sessions best before afternoon wind
Check local surf reports for conditions
Gulf waves are smaller than ocean—adjust expectations

operators.name: Port Aransas Surf School
operators.description: Lessons for all ages and abilities

faqs.question: Are there waves for surfing?
faqs.answer: Yes, but they're smaller than ocean waves. Gulf swells are typically 2-4 feet, occasionally bigger during storms and winter.

faqs.question: When's the best time to surf?
faqs.answer: Fall and winter have best swells. Summer is calm but good for beginners. Morning is best any time of year.

name: Stand-Up Paddleboarding
description: Explore calm bays and coastal waterways on a stand-up paddleboard with views above the water.
longDescription: Stand-up paddleboarding (SUP) has exploded in popularity in Port Aransas, thanks to the calm bay waters, marsh channels, and sheltered waterways perfect for paddling. The elevated vantage point lets you spot fish, rays, and dolphins below the surface. Guided eco-tours take you through birding habitats, sunrise sessions offer magical light, and rentals are available throughout town.
tips: Paddle into wind first so return is easier

faqs.question: Is paddleboarding hard to learn?
faqs.answer: Most people stand within minutes. Start on your knees, then work up to standing. Calm bay water makes learning easy.

faqs.question: What if I fall off?
faqs.answer: You'll probably fall a few times—it's part of learning! The water is warm, and you're attached to the board by a leash.

name: Kayaking
description: Paddle through marsh channels, birding areas, and coastal waterways in a kayak.
longDescription: Kayaking opens up Port Aransas's hidden waterways—marsh channels, mangrove edges, and birding habitats inaccessible by larger boats. The Leonabelle Turnbull Birding Center has a designated paddle trail, and Mustang Island State Park offers marked routes through coastal wetlands. Guided eco-tours combine paddling with wildlife education, while rentals let you explore independently.
bestTime: Morning for wildlife and calm water
tips: Tandem kayaks are easier for beginners
Paddle trails marked at state park
Watch for alligators—they're not aggressive but give space
locations: Mustang Island State Park Paddle Trail

faqs.question: Where are the best paddle trails?
faqs.answer: Mustang Island State Park has marked trails. Leonabelle Turnbull Birding Center is excellent for wildlife.

faqs.question: Are there alligators?
faqs.answer: Yes, in freshwater and brackish areas. They're not aggressive but maintain distance if you see one.

name: Dolphin Watching
description: See bottlenose dolphins in their natural habitat on boat tours through the ship channel and Gulf.
longDescription: Port Aransas is home to a resident population of bottlenose dolphins that frequently delight visitors. Dolphin watching cruises head through the ship channel and into the Gulf, where playful pods are almost always spotted. The dolphins often bow-ride alongside boats, leap from the water, and put on a show. Sighting rates are extremely high, making this a reliable and magical wildlife experience.
tips: Dolphins are curious and often approach boats
Also see pelicans, herons, and sometimes sea turtles

operators.name: Port Aransas Dolphin Watch
operators.description: Multiple daily cruises with high success rate

faqs.question: Will we definitely see dolphins?
faqs.answer: Sighting rate is over 95%. The resident population is reliable, and captains know where to find them.

faqs.question: How close do dolphins come?
faqs.answer: Often very close—they're curious and frequently approach boats to bow-ride or investigate.

name: Birdwatching
description: World-class birding destination with 500+ species including rare whooping cranes.
longDescription: The Port Aransas area is internationally recognized as one of North America's premier birding destinations. Located on the Central Flyway, the region sees millions of migratory birds in spring and fall. Resident species include roseate spoonbills, great blue herons, and numerous shorebirds. The endangered whooping cranes winter nearby at Aransas National Wildlife Refuge. Multiple sanctuaries, boardwalks, and guided tours cater to birders of all levels.
tips: Leonabelle Turnbull is best free site

operators.name: Coastal Bend Birding Tours
operators.description: Expert-guided tours including whooping crane trips

faqs.question: When can I see whooping cranes?
faqs.answer: November through March at Aransas National Wildlife Refuge. Boat tours offer best views.

faqs.question: What birds are unique to the area?
faqs.answer: Roseate spoonbills are stunning year-round. Great blue herons, reddish egrets, and many shorebirds are common.

name: Shelling
description: Hunt for beautiful shells along the beaches, especially after storms at San Jose Island.
longDescription: Shelling along the Port Aransas beaches can yield everything from sand dollars and whelks to olive shells and the prized lettered olive. The best shelling occurs after storms when waves deposit fresh shells on the beach. For serious shellers, boat tours to uninhabited San Jose Island offer pristine picking grounds with far less competition. Early morning, low tide, and post-storm conditions are ideal.
bestTime: Low tide, early morning, after storms
tips: San Jose Island has best selection

operators.name: Port Aransas Shelling Tours
operators.description: Boat tours to San Jose Island

faqs.question: What shells can I find?
faqs.answer: Whelks, olive shells, sand dollars (often broken), coquinas, scallops, and occasionally lettered olives.

faqs.question: Is San Jose Island worth the trip?
faqs.answer: Yes—the uninhabited beach has less traffic and better selection, especially after weather events.

name: Sunset Viewing
description: Experience spectacular Texas coast sunsets over the Gulf of Mexico.
longDescription: Port Aransas sunsets are legendary—the sky transforms into brilliant oranges, pinks, and purples as the sun sinks over the Gulf. The best viewing spots include Roberts Point Park, the beach at any access point, sunset cruises on the water, and rooftop bars. The wide horizon and clean air create optimal conditions for colorful displays. Sunset cruises combine the view with dolphins and drinks.
tips: Roberts Point and beaches face west

faqs.question: Best spot for sunsets?
faqs.answer: Roberts Point Park has channel views, any beach access works, or take a sunset cruise for on-water experience.

name: Parasailing
description: Soar 500-800 feet above the Gulf for breathtaking aerial views of the coast.
longDescription: Parasailing from Port Aransas offers a thrilling perspective of the Texas coast, lifting you 500-800 feet above the Gulf for panoramic views. The experience is surprisingly peaceful once aloft—you hear nothing but wind and can see for miles. Single, tandem, and triple flights accommodate groups. Takeoff and landing are from the boat, so you don't even need to get wet unless you want to.
tips: Photos are included with many operators

operators.name: Island Parasailing
operators.description: Multiple daily flights, photo packages available

faqs.question: Is parasailing safe?
faqs.answer: Very safe with licensed operators. Modern equipment and trained crews make incidents rare.

faqs.question: Will I get wet?
faqs.answer: Only if you request a dip! Takeoff and landing are from the boat deck.

name: Jet Skiing
description: Rent a jet ski for thrilling rides through the bay and Gulf waters.
longDescription: Jet skiing in Port Aransas provides high-speed fun on the water. Rentals include safety instruction, life jackets, and mapped riding areas through the bay and channel. Single and double jet skis accommodate individuals and pairs. The calm bay waters are perfect for beginners, while more experienced riders can explore further.

faqs.question: How old do you have to be?
faqs.answer: 16 to operate, but passengers can be younger with appropriate life jackets.

name: Golf Cart Touring
description: Cruise Port Aransas in a rented golf cart—the quintessential island transportation.
longDescription: Golf carts are street legal in Port Aransas, making them the perfect way to explore the island. Rent a cart and cruise to restaurants, shops, and beach access points in laid-back style. It's part transportation, part activity—families love the open-air experience, and finding parking is never a problem. Daily and weekly rentals are available with delivery to your property.

operators.name: Port A Golf Cart Rentals
operators.description: Daily and weekly rentals with delivery

name: Beach Bonfires
description: Gather around a beach bonfire under the stars for a memorable evening.
longDescription: Beach bonfires are permitted on Port Aransas beaches under certain conditions and with proper permits. Companies offer bonfire setups complete with wood, chairs, s'mores supplies, and cleanup. It's a magical way to end a beach day—watching flames dance under starry skies, listening to waves, and making vacation memories.
requirements: Fire must be in designated areas
tips: Bonfire services handle permits and cleanup

name: Nature & Wildlife Photography
description: Capture stunning images of wildlife, sunsets, and coastal landscapes.
longDescription: Port Aransas offers exceptional photography opportunities for all skill levels. The birding centers provide easy access to herons, spoonbills, and other wading birds. Beaches deliver stunning sunrises and sunsets. The marshes and bays offer moody landscapes. Whether you're shooting with a phone or professional gear, the light, wildlife, and scenery deliver memorable images.
tips: Birding centers have boardwalks for stability
Watch for sea spray on lenses
Polarizing filter helps with water reflections

name: Kiteboarding
description: Harness Port Aransas's reliable winds for exhilarating kiteboarding sessions.
longDescription: Port Aransas's consistent winds make it one of Texas's best kiteboarding destinations. The flat, shallow waters of the bay provide ideal learning conditions, while the Gulf offers more challenging waves for advanced riders. Lessons are available for beginners, and the sport's popularity has created a community of local kiters.
tips: Take lessons—don't try to teach yourself

name: Beach Horseback Riding
description: Ride horses along the beach for a romantic and memorable coastal experience.
longDescription: Beach horseback riding combines two quintessential experiences—horses and the beach. Guided rides take you along the sand at the water's edge during sunrise or sunset for an unforgettable experience. Rides accommodate all skill levels, from first-timers to experienced equestrians. It's romantic, peaceful, and provides unique beach photos.
tips: Sunset rides are most popular—book ahead

name: Sailing
description: Set sail on the bay and Gulf waters aboard chartered sailboats.
longDescription: Sailing from Port Aransas takes you into the bay and Gulf under wind power alone. Charter options range from skippered cruises where you relax and enjoy, to bareboat rentals for experienced sailors. The consistent coastal winds make for reliable sailing conditions, and the scenery—dolphins, pelicans, distant oil rigs—adds to the experience.

name: Sand Castle Building
description: Build sand castles on Port Aransas beaches—or hire pros for amazing sculptures.
longDescription: Sand castle building is a beloved beach activity, from simple kid-made creations to elaborate sculptures. Port Aransas hosts Sandfest, one of the largest sand sculpture competitions in the country, each spring. Professional sand sculptors offer lessons and can create spectacular custom pieces. The fine sand and consistent moisture make for good building conditions.
tips: Build at water's edge for moist sand
Use spray bottle to keep it damp
